intro: Sida sucupirana, commonly known as the Brazilian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and broad, palmate leaves. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically during the warmer months. Sida sucupirana is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and riverbanks. Its fibrous roots and leaves have been used traditionally in folk medicine for their purported healing properties.
